Correct. Example config from provided link:
switch# configure terminal
switch(config)# interface fc 2/4
switch(config-if)# switchport mode SD
switch(config-if)# switchport speed 1000
switch(config-if)# exit
switch(config)# monitor session 2
switch(config-monitor)# destination interface fc 2/4

Selected Answer: AE
A and E

choices.B: Configure the switchport monitor under interface fc2/2.
choices.A: Configure switchport speed 4000 under interface fc2/2.
choices.D: Configure the switchport mode SD under interface fc2/1.
choices.E: Configure the switchport mode SD under interface fc2/2.
choices.C: Configure session type fc under monitor session 1.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer implements SPAN configuration on an Nexus 5000 series switch. Which two commands are necessary to complete the SPAN session configuration?

comments.content:
you are right - An iSCSI target and initiator should be in the same subnet. 
C looks like the right option
Multipathing is about multiple IP paths, which rules out any bundling of physical interfaces. D is correct.

discussion.content:
D is wrong according to 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus1000/sw/4_2_1_s_v_1_5_1/system_management/configuration/guide/n1000v_system/n1000v_system_13iscsi.html#wp1052813

shouldn't it be C??

Selected Answer: D
Option D (initiators and targets in separate subnets) is preferred for achieving iSCSI multipathing because it allows for multiple independent network paths, enabling effective load balancing and failover.

Option B (bonding two NICs on the initiator) is less suitable because NIC bonding creates a single logical interface, limiting true multipathing capabilities. It lacks the granular path management needed for iSCSI multipathing, as it abstracts the individual interfaces, preventing the initiator from managing multiple discrete paths effectively.

Option D is correct for iSCSI multipathing.

Selected Answer: B
B. two NICs bonded together on the initiator

Explanation:

For optimal multipathing in iSCSI traffic, using two NICs bonded together on the initiator provides redundancy and increased throughput. This design ensures:
 1. Redundancy: If one NIC fails, the other continues to handle traffic without disruption.
 2. Load Balancing: Traffic can be distributed across the two NICs to improve performance.
 3. Multipathing Support: When properly configured with a multipath I/O (MPIO) solution, bonded NICs enable efficient path failover and management.

Recommended design is D) 
C and D are possible options but D) is more recommended.
Answer: D)

Selected Answer: C
Per VM documentation https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-4C19E34E-764C-4069-9D9F-D0F779F2A96C.html

Looks like we have 2 answers for this question which is C&D.
Port binding on Initiator will allow to create multiple paths to single target.
We can create multiple paths by configuring multiple ports and target portals on different IP subnets. In this situation port binding is not in use.
In this particular question I would reply C but we should have possibility to choose 2 answers.

I found other sources of this same exam, that appears to be a 2 choises question:
"What are two recommended design choices in a topology for multipathing iSCSI traffic? (Choose two.)

A: two NICs bonded together on the initiator
B: dual initiators to a single target with bonded interfaces
C: initiators and targets in separate subnets
D: dual initiators to dual targets
E: single initiator to dual targets"

In this case, would be B and C.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
D is right, because there will be two subnets for each two initiator and two targets

I think this makes more sense:
https://blog.spotodumps.com/index.php/2020/11/10/nov-2020-new-2020-ccie-ccnp-350-601-dccor-dumps-with-vce-and-pdf-from-spoto-update-questions/
The storage system is just what it is, what is usually redundant is the cabling (network) and the initiator of the communication itself, eg two cards in case one fails. So dual initiator instead of dual target.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/mds9000/sw/5_0/configuration/guides/ipsvc/nxos/ipsvc/ciscsi.html#53504
As you can see here there are many HA (High availability) solutions but the multi-path one uses different subnets between initiators and targets.

Answer D seems to be correct: 

You can create multiple paths by configuring multiple ports and target portals on different IP subnets. By keeping initiator and target ports in different subnets, you can force ESXi to create paths through specific ports. In this configuration, you do not use port binding because port binding requires that all initiator and target ports are on the same subnet.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-4C19E34E-764C-4069-9D9F-D0F779F2A96C.html

I think it´s option A.
Because multipath it's about redundancy on the destination or target for the initiator, so I think the best answer it´s A.
Any reference, please?

choices.C: dual initiators to a single target with bonded interfaces
choices.D: initiators and targets in separate subnets
choices.B: two NICs bonded together on the initiator

questions.question_text: What is a recommended design choice in a topology for multipathing iSCSI traffic?
questions.answer_description:
You can create multiple paths by configuring multiple ports and target portals on different IP subnets. By keeping initiator and target ports in different subnets, you can force ESXi to create paths through specific ports. In this configuration, you do not use port binding because port binding requires that all initiator and target ports are on the same subnet.
Reference:
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-4C19E34E-764C-4069-9D9F-D0F779F2A96C.html

choices.B: check the impact of the upgrade using the show install all impact command
choices.C: free up space on the USB3 device by deleting old Cisco NX-OS image files
choices.D: make the primary supervisor the active supervisor

B and E

questions.question_text: Which solution provides remote and direct file-level access to users and systems?

discussion.content: The correct answer should be "A and B" since you cannot perform upgrade on individual VDC. Upgrade is performed simultaneously for all VDCs on the same physical node..

Selected Answer: AB
A Virtual Port-Channel allows a device which is physically connected to two different Nexus switches to ‘think’ it is connected to a single device.

 The Hot Standby Router Protocol, HSRP, provides a mechanism which is
 designed to support non-disruptive failover of IP traffic in certain
 circumstances. In particular, the protocol protects against the
 failure of the first hop router when the source host cannot learn the
 IP address of the first hop router dynamically.
When you upgrade the Cisco NX-OS software, you upgrade the software for all virtual device contexts (VDCs) on the physical device. You cannot upgrade the Cisco NX-OS software for an individual VDC.

A and B is correct.
vPC - L2 and L3 multipathing and link redundancy
HSRP- L3 redundancy (gateway)

To complement "MaxG" response, MLAG doesn’t support L3 multipathing.

Selected Answer: AB
A and B

Selected Answer: AB
It's A and B

Selected Answer: AB
upgrade reloads the switches it's including all the VDC's.
It's A and B

A and B are correct. Just to add additional context. MLAG (Multi-chassis Link Aggregation) is a non-standard protocol that enables Layer 2 multipathing from the host to gain either additional bandwidth or link resiliency. It’s a public protocol so that every vendor can support MLAG by using their own custom rolled implementation of it. Cisco's implementation of MLAG is vPC, which is Cisco proprietary and only works between the same model of Cisco switches running the same version of NX-OS.

A and B, because you cannot perform upgrade on individual VDC. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/7_x/nx-os/upgrade/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_7000_Series_NX-OS_Software_Upgrade_and_Downgrade_Guide_Release_7-x.html
Why not A and D?
It's vPC & HSRP
I think and answer is A and B which are High Availability options VDC does not make sence in this context to me unless I am missing something.
